frameDefinitions: A Resource is depleted by some process, resulting in there being only a Remainder in existence some time into or after the process.
An Agent causes an Impactor to make sudden, forcible contact with an Impactee, or manipulates two (or more) Impactors so that they make mutual forcible contact.
An Agent causes a Theme to move from a Source, along a Path, to a Goal.
This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.
Generally without overall (translational) motion,  an Agent places a Theme at a location, the Goal, which is profiled.

An Agent causes a Theme to move with respect to a certain Fixed_location, generally with a certain Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape.
frameExamples: There are only two poems <t>left</t> from Quayle
He <t>slammed</t> his fist down on the table and bellowed something unintelligible.
She <t>threw</t> her shoes into the dryer .
David <t>placed</t> his briefcase on the floor.
listRoleDefinitions: The part of the Resource that the Process has not yet applied to.
The original set of items to which the Depletive_process applies one after the other.
The individual who owned the Resource that is being depleted.

A temporal setting or event which metonymically stands for the entities that were in existence then. The <fen>Remainder</fen> is part of the <fen>Original_context</fen>. This role occurs especially when abstract entities such as social institutions are seen as <fen>Resource</fen>s.
The Time when the amount of the Resource that is let is assessed.
The <fen>Impactee</fen> is the entity which is hit by the <fen>Impactor</fen>.
The <fen>Impactor</fen> is the entity that hits the <fen>Impactee</fen> because of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s efforts.
The <fen>Impactors</fen> are the multiple entities that collide.
The <fen>Agent</fen>  causes an impact.

The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, 
typically non-human, force that causes an <fen>Impactor</fen> to make sudden, 
forcible contact with an Impactee.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen>  when the impact occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>.  The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
The role <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
The role <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion.
The role <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

The role <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person (or other force) that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to move.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the object that changes location during the Placing.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the location where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up. This role is profiled by words in this frame.
<fen>Time</fen> is when the Placing occurs
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the Placing occurs.
<fen>Theme</fen> identifies the object involved in motion.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act.
This role identifies the part of the Agent's body being used to manipulate the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fen>Cause</fen> identifies the non-agentive force that causes the motion in place.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the event occurs.
This role  identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the event occurs.
listRoleExamples: Only two poems are left <fex>from Virgil Smithers</fex>
Only the Beaux Arts cinema is left <fex>from the golden era of the 1940s</fex>
<fex>In 1910</fex>, only two of the Renaissance buildings remained
What I want to know is who smacked <fex>my head</fex> with a 10-ton truck?
Those hoodlums strike my car <fex>with water balloons</fex> every day!
Mr. Addams likes to collide <fex>toy trains</fex> at high speed.
<fex>One juggler</fex> was hitting the ceiling with every other ball.
<fex>A violent explosion</fex>rattled the windows.
A postman rammed his Fiat Panda into a getaway car <fex>after spotting the burglars </fex> .
Father Shanahan , of Rushey Mead , Leicester , rammed his Datsun into another car <fex>on the way to the city 's Gilroes cemetery</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> threw the china at the wall.
Pat threw <fex>the china</fex> at the wall.
Pat dragged the box <fex>out of the cupboard</fex>.
I pushed the trolley <fex>along the street</fex>.
Kim threw the cat <fex>into the garden</fex>.
Kim pushed the lawnmower <fex>around the garden</fex>.
<fex>The storm</fex> tossed the sailor from the boat
The fireman dragged the injured driver <fex>clear</fex>
Paul pulled Fran upright <fex>from her sitting position</fex>.
We shoved half of the cargo overboard <fex>on the 29th</fex>.
<fex>The boy</fex> swung his legs.
Pat yawned (*his mouth).
There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
<fex>The waiter</fex> placed the food on the table.
The waiter placed <fex>the food</fex> on the table.
The waiter placed the food <fex>on the table</fex>.
Grass , which is sown with clover , provides rich pasture for cattle in summer and the clover is <fex>another plant which</fex> puts nitrogen into the soil .
Smithers had placed the table there <fex>the night before</fex>.
Kim twirled the glass <fex>in his fingers</fex>.
<fex>The wind</fex> vibrated the string.
